excerpt: https://arxiv.org/abs/1801.10198">Memory-Compressed Attention, in Pytorch. This repository offers both the causal and non-causal variant, and will take care of the padding if the sequence length is not divisible by the compression ratio. The code also resolves an edge-case where the very first query have no keys to attend to in the auto-regressive scenario. The solution is to use null key/values, appended to the final compressed set, so that there is always at least 1 key for all queries to attend to. ## Install ```bash $ pip install memory_compressed_attention ``` ## Usage ```python import torch from memory_compressed_attention import MemoryCompressedAttention attn = MemoryCompressedAttention( dim = 512, heads = 8, # number of heads causal = False, # auto-regressive or not compression_factor = 3, # compression ratio dropout = 0.1 # dropout post-attention

description.excerpt: Implementation of Memory-Compressed Attention, from the paper "Generating Wikipedia By Summarizing Long Sequences"

usage.excerpt:
```python
import torch
from memory_compressed_attention import MemoryCompressedAttention

attn = MemoryCompressedAttention(
    dim = 512,
    heads = 8,                 #: number of heads
    causal = False,            #: auto-regressive or not
    compression_factor = 3,    #: compression ratio
    dropout = 0.1              #: dropout post-attention
)

x = torch.randn(1, 1024, 512)
mask = torch.ones(1, 1024).bool()

attn(x, input_mask = mask) #: (1, 1024, 512)
```
